questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the condition in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the X ray, Shenton's line is broken and the acetabulum is empty, hence the hip is dislocated.
  • Now the difficulty is to identify whether the dislocation is anterior or posterior. These can be differentiated only by looking at the deformity of the limb.
  • In anterior hip dislocation, the deformity is flexion, abdution, external rotation and in posterior dislocation, its flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • In this x ray, the femur is adducted, hence it is posterior dislocation of hip.

questions.text: A 40-year-old motorcyclist sustains a high-energy pelvic impact and presents with groin pain and a shortened, internally rotated limb. An xray was done and showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In this rare injury, the femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum towards the pelvic cavity. The displacement of the head varies from the minimal to as much as the whole head lying inside the pelvis.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are inevitable. Therefore, the aim of treatment in these cases is to achieve as congruous an articular surface as possible.
  • For this, skeletal traction is applied distally and laterally. If the fragments fall in place and reasonably reconstitute the articular margins, the traction is continued for 8-12 weeks. In some young individuals, in whom the fragments do not fall back in place by traction, surgical reconstruction of the acetabular floor may be necessary.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior dislocation of hip (Option A) presents with limb held in flexion, abduction, and external rotation without acetabular wall fracture.

Posterior dislocation of hip (Option B) characterised by limb flexion, adduction, and internal rotation; the femoral head remains posterior to the acetabulum.

Intertrochanteric fracture of femur (Option D) shows a fracture line through the femoral neck and greater/lesser trochanters with lateral displacement, not medial pelvic migration.

choices.text: CT scan of his right hip
Skeletal traction on the distal femur to relax tension on the sciatic nerve

questions.text: An 18-year-old male sustains a right hip injury after being tackled on the football field. Figure shows his radiograph upon presentation to the emergency room three hours later. On physical exam, he is noted to have a foot drop and decreased sensation globally throughout his entire lower leg. Closed reduction under conscious sedation is immediately performed, and the hip is able to be ranged through a stable arc of motion following reduction. A post-reduction radiograph is shown in Figure. Shortly after the reduction, the patient continues to have a foot drop, but his sensation is slightly improved. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Following successful reduction of a traumatic hip dislocation, a CT scan must be obtained to evaluate for any entrapped osteochondral fragments.
  • Traumatic hip dislocations are typically the result of high-energy trauma and are frequently associated with posterior wall acetabular fractures. Initial management of a traumatic hip dislocation, with or without a fracture, is immediate closed reduction under conscious sedation.
  • If closed reduction is unsuccessful, immediate open reduction in the operating room should be performed.
  • Following successful reduction, a CT scan is necessary to rule-out intra-articular osteochondral fragments, even in the absence of fracture on radiographs. The incidence of sciatic nerve palsy following a traumatic hip dislocation is roughly 10%.

Explanation of Other Options:

Exploration of his sciatic nerve (Option A): Acute exploration of the sciatic nerve is controversial and shouldn't be entertained before a CT scan has been completed.

Electromyography (EMG) (Option B): EMG scan may be useful if the sciatic nerve fails to recover after a period of weeks to months.

Skeletal traction on the distal femur (Option D): Skeletal traction is not necessary if the hip is stable after concentric reduction and there are no associated fractures.

questions.text: A 36 year old male was involved in a 2 wheeler accident and sustained injury to his right hip. On examination, the hip is adducted. Flexed and internally rotated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Flexion, adduction and internal rotation deformity is the classical presentation of posterior dislocation of hip. There will also be associated shortening and femoral head will be palpable in the gluteal region.
  • In case of anterior dislocation there will be flexion abduction and external rotation deformity present.
  • There may be true lengthening, with the head palpable in the groin.
  • Prompt recognition and reduction within six hours are crucial to reduce risks of sciatic nerve injury and avascular necrosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior dislocation (Option A) presents with flexion, abduction, and external rotation of the limb and true lengthening, with the femoral head palpable in the groin.

Central dislocation (Option C) involves medial displacement of the femoral head through a fractured acetabular wall into the pelvis; limb rotation may be variable.

Fracture dislocation (Option D) includes ipsilateral fractures of the acetabulum or proximal femur with displacement; the pure rotational deformity of flexion, adduction, and internal rotation is not typical.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman presents eight months after sliding-hip-screw fixation of an unstable intertrochanteric femur fracture. She reports a persistent limp. Radiographs show solid union with 1 cm shortening and varus angulation. Which complication does this represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Malunion occurs when an intertrochanteric femur fracture heals with residual varus angulation and limb-length discrepancy despite solid bony union, and is the most common complication after intertrochanteric (extracapsular) femur fractures.
  • Although intertrochanteric fractures generally unite reliably due to their rich metaphyseal blood supply, imperfect reduction or controlled dynamic collapse along the sliding hip screw construct can result in residual deformity.
  • Patients with malunion often present with a persistent limp or altered gait, and severe cases may require corrective osteotomy to restore proper alignment and function.

Explanation of Other Options:

Non-union (Option B) is rare in extracapsular fractures because of robust metaphyseal blood flow and stable fixation constructs.

Avascular necrosis (Option C) is the most common complication of intracapsular neck fractures disrupting femoral head blood supply, not in intertrochanteric injuries.

Osteoarthritis (Option D) involves joint cartilage degeneration; the hip joint is spared in extracapsular fractures.

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady, after a history of fall, presents with pain in her left hip with external rotation and deformity of the hip. On examination, there was tenderness and broadening of the trochanter. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Intertrochanteric femur fracture: There will be swelling in the region of the hip, and the leg will be shortened and externally rotated. There is tenderness over the greater trochanter and broadening of the greater trochanter.
  • In case of neck femur fracture and subtrochanteric femur fracture, the GT will be normal.

Explanation of Other Options:

Neck of femur fracture (Option B) presents with leg shortening and external rotation but without trochanteric widening or palpable broadening.

Subtrochanteric femur fracture (Option C) occurs below the trochanters; tenderness is felt more distally on the femoral shaft.

Anterior dislocation of hip (Option D) manifests with flexion, abduction, and external rotation, not broadening of the trochanter.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents after a fall onto the hip and reports thigh pain. On examination, you perform the vascular sign of Narath by palpating for the femoral pulse against the femoral head in the inguinal region. In which of the following conditions would this sign not be positive?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a subtrochanteric femur fracture, the femoral head remains in the acetabulum, so the vascular sign of Narath is not elicited.
  • Vascular sign of Narath: inability to feel femoral pulse against femoral head in the inguinal region.
    • It is positive in all conditions where the femoral head is not present in its normal position. Eg. Traumatic hip dislocation, DDH, Tom Smith arthritis and Girdlestone arthroplasty

Useful signs in orthopaedics:

questions.text: Judet view X-rays are taken for which bone?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Judet views are oblique views of pelvis and include iliac oblique (45° external) and obturator oblique (45° internal) views and better help to delineate an acetabular fracture.

Multiple special projections exist for targeted evaluation of specific bones and joints.

SPECIAL VIEWS

Explanation of Other Options:

Scaphoid (Option B): Scaphoid fractures are best seen on dedicated scaphoid (oblique) wrist views.

Calcaneum (Option C): Calcaneal fractures use lateral and axial (Harris) foot views, not Judet projections.

Shoulder (Option D): Shoulder injuries employ true anteroposterior, scapular-Y, and axillary views rather than pelvic obliques.

questions.text: A 79-year-old lady presents with history of fall. There is right sided intertrochanteric fracture of hip evidenced by the given X-ray. Best management for this patient is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • X-ray image shows intertrochanteric femur fracture which is more common in elderly people with osteoporotic bones
  • In elderly population the intertrochanteric fracture is usually sustained by a sideway fall or a blow over the greater trochanter.
  • Most of these undisplaced fractures unite by themselves if femoral neck-shaft angle is maintained. Done by conservative means like traction (require bed rest of 3-4 months).
  • In elderly population internal fixation in form of Dynamic hip screw (DHS) or Proximal femoral nailing (PFN) is the treatment of choice. Prolonged bed rest in elderly is best avoided as it can cause further complications like pneumonia, bed sores etc.

questions.text: A 50 year old male was involved in a RTA and sustained injury to his pelvis. X-ray taken is given below. Identify fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The x ray shows fractures of right superior and inferior pubic rami with disruption of the ipsilateral sacroiliac joint. This is what is known as Malgaigne's fracture.
  • This injury represents a vertical shear through both the anterior and posterior pelvic rings, rendering the pelvis unstable and at risk for significant hemorrhage.
  • Early recognition and prompt surgical stabilization (e.g., internal fixation of the SI joint and pubic rami) are crucial to restore pelvic stability and reduce morbidity.

Explanation of Other Options:

Straddle fracture (Option B) involves bilateral fractures of the superior and inferior pubic rami without associated sacroiliac joint disruption.

Sacroiliac joint dislocation only (Option C) would show SI joint widening or displacement without pubic ramus fractures.

Duverney's fracture (Option D) is an isolated iliac wing fracture that spares the pelvic ring's continuity, maintaining relative stability.

questions.text: Gallow's traction is used for which of the following fractures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is used in infants and children with femoral shaft fractures.
  • Child must weigh less than 12 kg
  • Skin must be intact
  • Both the fractured and the well femur are placed in skin traction and the infant is suspended by these from a special frame.
  • Vascular compromise and compartment syndrome are the biggest dangers.
  • Check the circulation twice daily such that the buttock is just off the bed.

Explanation of Other Options:

Neck of femur (Option A) is treated with spica casting or surgical fixation in children; not suited to overhead skin traction.

Shaft of tibia (Option C) is managed with plaster cast or fixed skeletal traction below the knee, not Gallow's setup.

Tibial plafond (Option D) requires ankle-spanning external fixation or internal fixation; Gallow's traction is not indicated.

questions.text: In which type of fracture neck of femur according to Garden's classification is the trabeculae of femoral neck, femoral head and acetabulum in alignment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In Garden type II all 3 trabeculae are collinear.
  • This preserved alignment indicates minimal disruption of the intracapsular blood supply, allowing stable fixation with a low risk of avascular necrosis.
  • The Garden classification is used to classify intracapsular proximal femur fractures (neck of femur fractures)

Garden Types (A) I, (B) II, (C) III, and (D) IV

choices.text: Closed reduction with cannulated screw fixation
Open reduction with cannulated screw fixation

questions.text: A 65-year-old female sustained the injury seen in Figure after a slip and fall. She is an avid golfer and walks the course on most days. Her past medical history includes borderline hypertension and migraine headaches. Which treatment option has shown to have the lowest re-operation rate and best clinical outcomes scores in this patient population?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Figure shows a displaced right femoral neck fracture in an active, healthy elderly patient.
  • Treatment of her hip fracture with total hip arthroplasty (THA) has shown to have the lowest re-operation rates and best functional outcome scores when compared to internal fixation devices and hemiarthroplasty.
  • Large studies have shown the incidence of femoral head AVN to be approximately 30-45% with displaced femoral neck fractures (Garden III-IV). For this reason, treatment of these injuries in elderly patients have supported arthroplasty over ORIF.
  • Treatment of patients with THA vs. hemiarthroplasty have also been investigated. Studies have shown that THA has lower re-operation rates and improved functional outcome scores in younger, active elderly patients compared to hemiarthroplasty.

Explanation of Other Options:

Closed reduction with cannulated screw fixation (Option A): Higher rates of avascular necrosis (30-45%) and nonunion necessitate frequent secondary procedures.

Open reduction with cannulated screw fixation (Option B): Surgical exposure does not overcome intracapsular healing risk; re-operation rates remain elevated.

Hemiarthroplasty (Option C): Preserves an arthritic acetabulum and yields less optimal function with higher revision rates than total hip arthroplasty in active elderly patients.

questions.text: The investigation of choice for identifying occult fracture neck of femur is.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Magnetic resonance imaging has near-100% sensitivity and specificity for detecting occult femoral-neck fractures by visualizing marrow edema and subtle fracture lines within hours of injury.
  • MRI avoids ionizing radiation and provides excellent anatomic detail, facilitating early diagnosis and management and reducing the risk of complications from missed fractures.
  • Although bone scans can detect occult fractures, they often require 48-72 hours for tracer uptake and offer less precise localization than MRI.

Explanation of Other Options:

X-ray (Option A) may miss nondisplaced or hairline femoral-neck fractures in up to 5-10% of cases due to lack of visible cortical disruption.

CT scan (Option B) provides good cortical bone detail but is less sensitive than MRI for detecting marrow changes and subtle non-displaced fractures.

Bone scan (Option D) sensitive only after a delay of 48-72 hours and lacks the specificity and anatomic resolution of MRI.

questions.text: 45 years old female with a history of fall, complains of pain in left hip and inability to walk. On examination there is tenderness in Scarpa's triangle. The X-ray is normal, next investigation to be ordered is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Based on clinical history, the patient must be having occult proximal femur fracture and MRI is the investigation of choice for occult fractures.
  • Magnetic resonance imaging has near-100% sensitivity and specificity for detecting occult femoral-neck fractures by visualizing marrow edema and subtle fracture lines within hours of injury.
  • MRI avoids ionizing radiation and provides excellent anatomic detail, facilitating early diagnosis and management and reducing the risk of complications from missed fractures.
  • Although bone scans can detect occult fractures, they often require 48-72 hours for tracer uptake and offer less precise localization than MRI.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aspiration (Option A) is used to evaluate for septic arthritis or hemarthrosis, not for diagnosing occult fractures.

Computed tomography (CT) (Option C) is better for cortical detail but less sensitive than MRI for early marrow changes and nondisplaced fractures.

Bone scan (Option D) can detect increased uptake in occult fractures but requires 48-72 hours post-injury and lacks MRI's anatomic precision.

questions.text: A 30-year-old motorcyclist sustains a femoral neck fracture with an associated femoral head fracture after a high-speed collision. According to the Pipkin classification, what grade describes this injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pipkin Grade III injuries consist of a femoral head fracture plus a femoral neck fracture.
  • This combination increases the risk of avascular necrosis and necessitates careful surgical planning, often requiring reduction and fixation of both fragments.
  • Recognition of a Grade III injury guides the surgeon toward open approaches (e.g., surgical hip dislocation) to achieve anatomic reduction of both head and neck fragments.
